question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
How many 3-digit numbers have a first digit which is triple the final digit?
inference:
Let the final digit be \(x\).
Then the first digit is \(3x\).
The middle digit can be any digit from \(0\) to \(9\), so there are \(10\) options for it.
So the total number of 3-digit numbers with a first digit which is triple the final digit is 
\(10\).
Final Answer: \boxed{10}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
There are only three possibilities for the first digit: \[
\begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline
\text{First digit} & \text{Last digit} \\ \hline
3 & 1 \\ \hline
6 & 2 \\ \hline
9 & 3 \\ \hline
\end{array}
\] The middle digit can be any of the $10$ digits. The answer is $3\times 10=\boxed{30}.$
